After evaluating your argument that "Obamacare used low rates as a shell game to hide high deductibles and co-pays," I partially disagree with you. 

While it's true that Obamacare health plans have typically been characterized by low monthly premiums and high deductibles and co-pays, it's not exactly a 'shell game'. The structure of these health programs were abundantly clear from the beginning and were designed this way to make monthly premiums more affordable. This aims at insuring more people who could not previously afford to do so.

I'd also like to stress the comprehensive nature of coverage provided by Obamacare. People with pre-existing conditions could no longer be denied coverage, and all plans had to cover an array of essential health benefits. 

But, an assertive judgment cannot be made based solely on these facts as it's worth investigating how users have felt about the trade-off between lower premiums and high out-of-pocket costs. Whether Obamacare is "working" or not can depend on individual contexts and perspectives. 

It's important to evaluate the entire range of Obamacare's impacts, rather than focusing only on one piece of the puzzle. Hence, the claim "Obamacare is not working" could be seen as an oversimplification.
